dictionaryTerms.title: Receivable
dictionaryTerms.content: A receivable is the right of a creditor (natural or legal person) to demand performance from a debtor arising from a certain obligation. A receivable can be monetary or non-monetary.

detailContent.intro: A receivable is the right of a creditor (natural or legal person) to demand performance from a debtor arising from a certain obligation. A receivable can be monetary or non-monetary. At the time of maturity, the creditor has the right to collect the receivable from the debtor, and the debtor has the obligation to settle this obligation towards the creditor.

sections.title: What is the difference between a receivable and a debt?
sections.content: A receivable is actually the right to performance arising from a certain obligation, which a certain person (creditor) has towards another participant in the obligation (debtor). On the contrary, against the receivable stands the so-called debt - that is, the obligation of the participant in the obligation to give something, refrain from something, do something or tolerate something.

sections.title: Types of receivables according to maturity
sections.content: A short-term receivable is due within 12 months. A long-term receivable has a maturity period longer than 12 months.

items.text: has a maturity period longer than 12 months.

dictionaryTerms.title: Promissory note
dictionaryTerms.content: A promissory note is a security containing an unconditional payment order or promise to pay a certain amount. There are several types of promissory notes, such as security promissory note, own promissory note, third-party promissory note, and others.

detailContent.intro: A promissory note is a security containing an unconditional payment order or promise to pay a certain amount.

sections.title: Security promissory note
sections.content: A promissory note can also serve as security for a monetary obligation and can be enforced after the obligation based on the original monetary obligation has not been fulfilled.

sections.title: Own promissory note
sections.content: Formed on the basis of two bill participants - the issuer and the remittent (the person to whose order or name the bill is issued). Contains an unconditional promise to pay ("I will pay").

dictionaryTerms.title: Debt assumption
dictionaryTerms.content: Debt assumption is a legal institute where a third party takes over a debt from the original debtor. The consent of the creditor is required for debt assumption.

detailContent.intro: Debt assumption is a legal institute where a third party takes over a debt from the original debtor. The consent of the creditor is required for debt assumption.
